ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant's senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The Utility Systems Supervisor administers the City's safety and environmental policies. The Utility Systems Supervisor is responsible for various inspections of the City's facilities to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs.  These programs include hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.





STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The facility has been in operation since 1973 but the water treatment system was modified in 1997 and the aqueous ammonia system was added in late 2002.  The process is located at 14521 Lake Poway Road, Poway, CA 92064.  



The chlorine system for the City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant consists of chlorine one-ton containers which are the storage vessels.  Chlorine gas is pulled from the one ton containers to the chlorinators through the vacuum regulator.  The chlorinators are equipped with water at the injectors and the resulting chlorine solution is distributed through rotameters to other water processes at the facility. 



Below provides a list of the chlorine equipment.



Chlorine One-Ton Containers (9) in the Storage Area

Vacuum Regulators (4) in the Storage Area

Chlorinators (4) in the Chlorinator Room (Chemical Building)

Injectors (6) in the Chlorinator Room (Chemical Building)

Scrubber System, Located at the south end of the facility.



The maximum quantity of chlorine that can be stored on site is 18,000 pounds.



The aqueous ammonia (20% concentration) is stored in a 6,000 gallon storage tank that resides in a co

ntainment area, however the facility has a policy and SOP to not fill the tank more than 4,600 gallons (approximately 36,000 pounds of aqueous solution).    A liquid pump draws the ammonia solution from the storage tank through plastic piping to the point of injection with softened water, which is then routed to the treated water to form chloramines in the water to reduce THM levels.  A combination pressure relief / vacuum breaker valve is located on top of the storage tank and relieves to a neutralization tank.  The valve protects the tank against excess pressure and vacuum conditions.



Below provides a list of the aqueous ammonia equipment.



Aqueous ammonia storage tank (1) in the Containment Basin

Neutralization Tank (1) (Stored in the Containment Basin)

Metering Pumps (2) in the Chemical Feed Building 

Flow Meter (1) in the Chemical Feed Building 

Ammonia Detector (1) in the Chemical Feed Building

Calibration Chamber (1) Inside Chemical Feed Building.



The maximum quantity of aqueous ammonia that can be stored on site is 36,000 pounds.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS - CHLORINE AND AQUEOUS AMMONIA



The chorine system at the City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the Uniform Mechanical Code, Uniform Building Code, and the Uniform Fire Code.  All of these codes serve to reduce the risk within the facility by specifying acceptable design criteria for the chorine system and on-site buildings.  In addition, the facility was designed in accordance with industry standards and with generally accepted engineering practices.



The aqueous ammonia system at the City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant is designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the 1997 Uniform Mechanical Code, Uniform Building Code, the Uniform Fire Code, the 1998 Californ

ia Building Code, the American Society for Testing and Materials, and the American Concrete Institute.  All of these codes serve to reduce the risk within the plant by specifying acceptable design criteria for the aqueous ammonia system and on-site buildings.  The system was designed and installed in accordance with industry standard and with generally accepted engineering practices. 



City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant has established a mechanical integrity program for maintaining and operating the chlorine and aqueous ammonia equipment and uses the Chlorine Manual from the Chlorine Institute as a basis.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



An investigation into the facility's accident history during the chlorine Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study (August 9, 2013) and the aqueous ammonia Hazard Review Revalidation study (July 30, 2012), revealed that there have been no significant releases of chlorine or aqueous ammonia at the facility in the last five years  (August 2008 - August 2013 and July 2007 - July 2012, respectively) that meet the specific RMP criteria for the Five-Year Accident History.  Such "RMP accidents" would involve serious accidents with either onsite deaths, injuries, or significant damage; or known, off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, or environmental damage.  In addition, there have been no significant releases of chlorine or aqueous ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 10 pounds of chlorine or 1,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material. In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a chlorine or aqueous ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation. 





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



If a release of chlorine or aqueous ammonia were to occur, the City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant's response plan is to call 911 in order to reach the Fir

e Department's HAZMAT team.  Employees will evacuate the facility to a point that is upwind of the hazard.  Evacuation drills are performed annually.  The emergency response plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations.  It is reviewed annually to ensure that the plan is kept current.  





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The City of Poway has taken a pro-active approach to emergency response and safety at the Water Treat Plant.  The annual emergency response drills are documented and mitigation measures to improve the Team's response are continuously being reviewed. City of Poway - Water Treatment Plant has implemented all recommendations from the initial technical studies, as well as all recommendations from the latest Process Hazard Analysis and Hazard Review Revalidations (August 9, 2013 and July 30, 2012, respectively). The recommendations from the PSM/RMP/CalARP Compliance Audits (January 6, 2014) are still in progress. 



The Process Safety Management team is planning to complete several items over the next year as their continued effort to provide a safe work environment for the City employees.  These changes include the following items:



1.    Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2.    Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.



3.    Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4.    Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
